newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft files three copyright lawsuits.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft files three copyright lawsuits.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. said on Friday it has filed copyright infringement lawsuits against three computer resellers for alleged illegal distribution of pirated software.

Based on consumer tips from the Microsoft Anti-Piracy Hotline and purchases made by "mystery shoppers" deployed at local computer stores, Microsoft said it had identified 11 computer dealers who were allegedly selling pirated software.

The company alleged that the dealers were either selling counterfeit software or installing unauthorised versions of software on computers for sale to the public -- an illegal practice known as hard-disk loading.
"Unlike legitimate software, pirated software doesn't come with any assurance of quality, any technical support, or any warranty," warned Jim Lowe, Microsoft's corporate attorney.
"And pirated software can infect your entire computer system with a virus, which can damage your hard disk or destroy all of your data."
Eight of the dealers signed voluntary settlements, agreeing to stop any software piracy and to compensate Microsoft for past losses, the company said.
Three dealers refused to sign settlement agreements, resulting in lawsuits being filed against the them, Microsoft said.
Redmond, Wash.-based Microsoft's stock rose 50 cents to $134.50 early on Nasdaq.
